Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 45118-001  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)  
June 2011 
 
 
 
Establishing the Asian International Economists 
Network  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ADBI  –  Asian Development Bank Institute 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
DMC  –  developing member country 
FTA   –  free trade agreement 
OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
TA  –  technical assistance 
WTO  –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Industry and trade (industry and trade sector development, trade 
and services) 
Themes  –  Regional cooperation and integration (trade and investments); 
(subthemes)  economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment); capacity development (client relations, 
network, and partnership development)  
Location impact  –  Regional (high), national (medium), urban (medium), rural (low) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Head  I. Azis, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Senior Director  A. Sharma, OREI 
   
Team leader  G. Wignaraja, Principal Economist, OREI 
Team member  W. Paz, Senior Economics Officer, OREI  
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION  
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been actively supporting trade and investment 
integration as a means to achieve its overarching objective of poverty reduction in Asia and the 
Pacific. ADB’s regional departments and the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
are engaged in various capacity development activities nationally or regionally to enhance the 
capacity of developing member countries (DMCs) to trade effectively and efficiently, thereby 
maximizing the benefits of trade policy and facilitation initiatives.  
 
2.  As  part  of  these  capacity  development  activities,  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  will 
establish  a  network  of  trade  experts  which,  through  targeted  outputs,  aims  to  strengthen 
institutional  capacity  on  trade  policy  across  the  region.  The  network  will  support  regional 
economic integration and is thereby anticipated to have a positive impact on cooperation among 
developing countries.1 It will also support continued globalization of the region’s trade and 
investment patterns and the region’s participation in the successful conclusion of the Doha 
Round of the World Trade Organization (WTO).2 
 
3.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy.3 The 
strategy defines trade and investment cooperation and integration as one of its four pillars 
(pillar 2). The strategy provides the basis for ADB’s capacity development initiatives in regional 
trade.  OREI  is  ADB’s  focal  point  for  pillar  2  and  has  expertise  in  research,  information 
dissemination, and capacity development pertaining to free trade agreements (FTAs), WTO 
agreements, and emerging trade policy issues. OREI is actively engaged with the WTO on trade 
policy issues through the Aid for Trade Initiative, the Regional Technical Group on Aid for Trade, 
and the WTO’s 2011 World Trade Report focusing on FTAs and multilateralizing regionalism. In 
addition, OREI is supporting the East Asia Department in its policy dialogue with the People’s 
Republic of China to speed up the creation of an East Asia free trade area, the Southeast Asia 
Department  as  peer  reviewer  for  trade  policy  loans,  and  the  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department in scaling up the Trade Finance Facilitation Program. The TA also stems from a 
request  made  by  Mari  Pangestu,  Indonesia’s  trade  minister  and  the  2011  chair  of  the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), during a meeting with President Kuroda on 13 
December 2010 at the ADB headquarters.4 
 
4.  The TA paper reflects the purpose and output, methodology and key activities, cost 
estimates and financing plan, and implementation arrangements of this project.5 The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Trade patterns are in a state of flux in the rapidly evolving post-global financial crisis 
world and, amid stalled Doha Round trade talks, there is a rapid spread of FTAs and a gathering 
momentum for large intra- and interregional FTA proposals (e.g., ASEAN+3, ASEAN+6, the 
Trans-Pacific  Partnership  Agreement,  and  the  Free  Trade  Agreement  of  the  Asia-Pacific). 
                                                 
1  This is often referred to as South-South cooperation. 
2  WTO. Doha Development Agenda. http://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dda_e/dda_e.htm 
3  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila. http://www.adb.org/documents/policies/rci-
strategy 
4  Indonesia is the chair of the ASEAN in 2011 and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation in 2013. 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 11 April 2011.

2 
Despite persistent and strong political signals from world leaders to conclude the Doha Round, 
and the resumption of negotiations in January 2011, it seems unclear whether economies will 
overcome disagreement over liberalization of agriculture and non-agricultural market access in 
the near future.6 Moreover, in the wake of high unemployment and increasing protectionist 
sentiments combined with a gathering momentum for regionalism, it is unclear where the much-
needed movement will come from. Instead, countries are seeking liberalization through bilateral 
and regional trade agreements. About 50 FTAs are in effect in East Asia alone, and many of 
them are comprehensive “new age” FTAs that include issues beyond goods and services. 
Furthermore, as trade liberalization inevitably brings adjustment to countries and sectors within 
them, there is increasing focus on winners and losers from trade agreements (both the WTO-
Doha Round and FTAs). Trade-related development assistance, including the WTO Aid-for-
Trade Initiative (which emphasizes increasing cross-border infrastructure, trade policy reform, 
and supply side competitiveness policies), is seen as a means to alleviate adjustment costs at 
the national and subregional levels.7 
 
6.  Accordingly,  however,  regional  trade  negotiations  are  becoming  more  complex  and 
difficult as they increasingly deal with matters that go beyond traditional tariff and nontariff 
barriers  and  tackle  topics  such  as  investment,  competition,  trade  facilitation,  government 
procurement, intellectual property rights, environment, and labor standards. Meanwhile, trade 
policy capacity (embodied in trade ministries and think tanks) varies significantly across the 
region, with notable gaps in low-income developing economies. There is a growing and urgent 
need  to  increase  the  capacity  of  the  region’s  trade  officials  and  think  tanks  to  analyze 
implications and formulate competitiveness-enhancing trade policies. Supporting the high-level 
global and regional dialogue on Aid for Trade (WTO global Aid-for-Trade review meetings, 
regional Aid-for-Trade review meetings, and the Regional Technical Group on Aid-for-Trade for 
Asia  and  the  Pacific)  and  the  preparation  of  analytical  reports  as  required  are  crucial  for 
developing a strategy for the region.  
 
7.  To  meet  this  need,  the  TA  will  set  up  an  open-ended,  internet-based  network  of 
international  economic  policy  experts  and  scholars  in  Asia—to  be  known  as  the  Asian 
International  Economists  Network—with  which  policymakers  can  interact  when  serious 
discussions about trade policies are required. The TA will also develop a database and online 
tools for trade policy analysis; organize training programs and conferences on new trade issues; 
provide opportunities for informal policy dialogues and roundtable discussions among trade 
ministers, ADB Management, and trade experts; run a research associates program on new 
trade issues; and undertake policy-oriented research. Issues will be prioritized according to 
demand from network participants.  
 
8.  A parallel and simultaneous development is the mainstreaming of trade-related work 
within ADB. ADB could consider at a later date the establishment of a trade group within the 
community  of  practice  on  regional  cooperation  and  integration  (RCI  CoP),  or  possibly  a 
separate community of practice on trade if warranted. The TA will draw on ADB’s experience in

multilateral trade negotiation to date.  
7  ADB Management has led efforts to support the WTO in implementing the Aid-for-Trade Initiative in the Asia-
Pacific. President Kuroda has emphasized the Two Faces of the Asia-Pacific and underlined the need for more 
Aid-for-Trade to close the gap. See President Kuroda’s speeches at the 2007 Regional Review Meeting in Manila 
and  the  2009  Global  Review  Meeting  in  Geneva.  http://aric.adb.org/aid-for-trade-asia/pdf/ADB_Pres  Kuroda

adb.org/Documents/Speeches/2009/ms2009052.asp.

supporting FTAs and trade policy capacity development for DMCs,8 knowledge outputs,9  and 
existing institutional links with DMCs, subregional entities, and regional development partners. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  stronger  national  and  regional  trade  policies  and 
cooperation of trade ministries, policymakers, and trade experts in Asia. Enhanced policies and 
cooperation  among  policymakers  and  trade  experts  in  the  region  will  lead  to  more  trade 
cooperation among developing countries, which is an important aspect of sustaining Asian and 
global economic recovery. 
 
10.  The outcome will be enhanced trade policy capacity among network members to deal 
with issues in second-generation FTA negotiations through analysis, policy formulation, and 
information creation and dissemination. The TA will also strengthen the engagement of ADB 
and the Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) with development partners (e.g., Organisation 
for Economic Co-operation and Development, World Bank, and WTO). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will cover the entire Asia and Pacific region. Taking on capacity development for 
such a large and diverse group of countries is a challenging task. The different trade and 
investment interests and needs across the region must therefore be taken into account in TA 
implementation, as one size does not fit all. Differentiated approaches might be needed. 
 
12.  The TA will have six major components.  
 
13.  Output 1: Creation of a platform for network interaction and development of a 
database and online tools for trade policy analysis. A virtual, web-based platform will be 
developed  to  facilitate  interaction  among  network  members.  The  network  will  be  centered 
around this new platform, accessible to all parties, so that network members can interact both 
virtually and at network events (such as conferences and policy dialogues). The network will 
consist of trade ministers and other officials involved in formulating trade policies (e.g., officials 
from finance ministries, commerce ministries), scholars, think tank researchers, ADB and ADBI 
staff, and other relevant parties from across the Asia and Pacific region. The network will be 
open to all regional groupings, (e.g., ASEAN, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, Boao Forum 
for  Asia,  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area, 
                                                 
8  Relevant TA projects include: ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building for Designing, Negotiating, 
and Implementing Free Trade Agreements in Selected Asian Developing Member Countries. Manila (TA 6345-

MacMillan/ADB; ADB and UNESCAP. 2009. Designing and Implementing Trade Facilitation in Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila; M. Kawai and G. Wignaraja. 2011. Asia’s Free Trade Agreements: How is Business Responding? 
Cheltenham, UK: Edward Elgar Publishing.

4 
Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation,  Greater  Mekong  Subregion,  Indonesia–
Malaysia–Thailand  Growth  Triangle,  the  Pacific  Islands  Forum,  South  Asia  Subregional 
Economic Cooperation, and South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation). Rules and 
regulations governing the operation of the network will be formulated by network members. 
Furthermore, network members, together with outside experts (as appropriate), will be engaged 
in the development of online tools for trade policy analysis using the platform of the Asia 
Regional Integration Center website. The web-based platform will also take stock of all trade-
related publications and activities of ADB and outputs of network members.  
 
14.  Output 2: Training programs on new trade issues. At least two training programs 
dealing with designing and implementing second-generation trade issues for negotiating FTAs 
and global trade agreements will be held during TA implementation. The content will cover the 
four Singapore issues (investment, competition, trade facilitation, government procurement)10 
and sensitive topics such as intellectual property rights, environment, and labor standards. It will 
be targeted at upgrading skills of middle-level and junior officials involved in formulating trade 
policies, negotiating trade agreements, and advising ministers. If there is demand, specialist 
courses dealing with individual new trade issues may also be conducted during the project, 
possibly  through  cofinancing.  To  the  extent  possible,  each  subregional  grouping  will  be 
represented in training courses. Training and information dissemination through e-learning will 
also be conducted using the network’s internet-based resources (output 1).  
 
15.  Output 3: Conferences on new trade issues. To sustain the network, two international 
conferences will be held during TA implementation. The conferences will focus on the latest 
developments in new trade issues in FTAs and global agreements, fine points of trade theory 
and legal aspects of new trade issues, examples of good practice, considerations of political 
economy, and Aid-for Trade issues at the global and regional levels, including the Regional 
Technical Group on Aid-for-Trade. Trade experts, senior trade officials, ministers, and ADB 
and/or ADBI staff will participate in these conferences. If there is sufficient demand, specialist 
conferences dealing with individual new trade issues may be undertaken through cofinancing. 
Trade ministers and eminent trade experts will be invited to give keynote lectures. Participation 
of network members will be in person or by videoconference, and the lectures will be recorded 
for repeat viewing by network members.  
 
16.  Output 4: Informal policy dialogues and roundtable discussions. To boost further 
interaction in the network, informal policy dialogues and roundtable discussions among trade 
ministers, the ADB Management, and trade experts will be held. These will discuss pros and 
cons of alternative policy choices and review best practices with a view to formulating policies 
and negotiating approaches to new trade issues. The Chatham House Rule will apply.  
 
17.  Output 5: A research associates program at ADB and/or ADBI on new trade issues. 
Up to six research associates will be engaged to support the work of the network, conduct 
research, and promote capacity development. Contracts ranging from 6 months to 1 year will be 
provided. Research associates will have a master’s degree in economics or law and a minimum 
of 2 years work experience. The positions will be advertised and selection based on merit.  
 
                                                 
10 These four issues are often referred to as "Singapore issues" because they formally became part of the WTO 
agenda  at  the  1996  Singapore  Ministerial  Conference.  The  four  subjects  were  later  included  in  the  Doha 
Development Agenda in 2001, but in 2004 the parties decided to proceed with negotiations in only one subject, 
(trade facilitation). Negotiations on some or all four topics are today present in most regional FTA negotiations.

5
18.  Output  6:  Policy-oriented  research. A training manual on best practices for trade 
negotiators, a series of short policy briefs and working papers, reports on emerging policy 
issues (including Aid-for-Trade and general equilibrium modeling of trade and economic issues), 
and a book of forward-looking essays written by leading trade experts and senior researchers 
will be published and made available through the websites of ADB and ADBI.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). Appendix 2 provides details of 
the cost estimates and financing plan. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency. OREI will be the focal point for the TA and will 
implement  the  TA  with  the  assistance  of  regional  departments,  ADBI,  the  Economics  and 
Research Department, and international and national consultants and resource persons. To 
maximize  synergies,  a  meeting  will  be  held  with  regional  departments  at  the  start  of  TA 
implementation to discuss directions, activities, inputs, and co-financing. The RCI CoP will be 
used for regular discussions (see para. 8). A small, full-time project secretariat based at the 
ADB headquarters will provide logistical and technical support. The secretariat will consist of a 
full-time project manager and a researcher, each to be engaged for 30 person-months. A trade 
economist or macroeconomist will be engaged intermittently for 9 person-months to prepare 
papers,  policy  briefs,  and  a  manual.  Through  the  research  associates  program,  up  to  six 
research  associates  will  be  engaged  as  consultants.  To  design  and  develop  the  network 
website, a web developer will be engaged intermittently for 6 person-months. Resource persons 
will  also  be  engaged  from  time  to  time  to  accomplish  short-term  activities  under  the  TA. 
Consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB individually in accordance with the Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.  Equipment for the database will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, amended from time to time). The equipment will be purchased through the 
ADB Procurement and Contracts Administration Unit and will be assigned to the secretariat of 
the  Asian  International  Economists  Network.  Upon  TA  completion,  the  equipment  will  be 
disposed of in compliance with ADB’s project administration instructions on administering grant-
financed technical assistance projects.11 
 
22.  A no-objection letter will be obtained before commencing or financing any undertaking in 
the  territory  of  any  DMC.  The  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, amended from time to time). The TA is expected to 
be completed within 36 months, from June 2011 to June 2014.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,100,000 on a grant basis 
for Establishing the Asian International Economists Network, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Asian International Economists Network Secretariat 
1.  Program Manager (international or national, individual, 30 person-months) 
1.  The program manager will have substantial knowledge of the economics and politics of 
Asian economies and strong program management skills; a master’s degree in international law 
or economics; at least 5 years relevant experience in the areas of international and regional 
trade; excellent writing and editing skills; excellent organizational and communication skills, and 
ability to meet tight time frames; excellent computer skills; and working knowledge of website 
use. Under the supervision of the project team leader and with other consultants, the program 
manager will 
(i)  Conduct overall program development and management 
(a)  Provide substantive inputs in developing the TA’s 3-year work program 
(b)  Establish and run the network secretariat 
(c)  Outline strategies to build support and interest from governments and 
business community 
(d)  Determine  potential  partners  and  key  stakeholders  to  be  involved  in 
network activities  
(e)  Provide substantive inputs in the design of new activities 
(f)  Assist in all technical and administrative matters  
(ii)  Arrange conferences and training programs on new trade issues and informal 
roundtable discussions among trade ministers, the ADB Management, and trade 
experts  
(a)  Design the program, develop participants list and coordinate logistical 
details for the conferences on new trade issues  
(b)  Design the components, including curriculum, and coordinate logistical 
details for training programs on new trade issues 
(c)  Arrange and coordinate logistical details for informal roundtables of trade 
ministers, the ADB Management, and trade experts 
(iii)  Manage a research associates program at ADB and/or ADBI on new trade issues  
(a)  Assist in the advertisement and recruitment of research associates  
(b)  Supervise and provide guidance to research associates 
(iv)  Manage the virtual platform and database development   
(a)  Provide  substantive  input  in  the  development  of  the  website,  virtual 
platform, and expanded online trade policy tools and database 
(b)  Coordinate development and updating of the website, virtual platform, 
and database in collaboration with web developers  
(v)  Perform outreach, research, and publication work 
(a)  Prepare policy briefs on new trade issues  
(b)  Draft outlines of handbooks on technical standards 
(c)  Edit and review written outputs of the TA  
(d)  Provide inputs in the publication of policy briefs, the training manual on 
best practices for trade negotiators, and other written outputs 
(e)  Provide inputs in the publication of the book of forward-looking essays by 
leading trade experts 
(f)  Ensure appropriate dissemination of project outputs 
(g)  Represent the network in relevant meetings 
(h)  Interact with relevant institutions 
(vi)  Undertake other related tasks as required by the OREI team leader.

Appendix 3  11 
 
2.  Researcher (national, individual, 30 person-months) 
2.   The researcher will have substantial knowledge of the economics and politics of Asian 
economies and strong research skills; a master’s degree in economics, international relations, 
or law; at least 3 years relevant experience in the areas of international and regional trade; 
excellent writing and editing skills; excellent computer skills; and some knowledge in website 
management. Under the supervision of the OREI team leader and the program manager, the 
researcher will 
(i)  Provide research and writing support to the network 
(ii)  Provide substantive inputs to website design, development, and maintenance 
(iii)  Ensure appropriate dissemination of project outputs 
(iv)  Represent the network in relevant meetings 
(v)  Interact with relevant institutions 
(vi)  Perform other tasks required to achieve TA objectives and as required by the 
OREI team leader and program manager. 
 
3.  Research Associates on new trade issues (international or national, individual, 
36 person-months, intermittent)  
 
3.  Research associates should have a master’s degree in economics or international law 
and a minimum of 2 years work experience. Up to six research associates at ADB and/or ADBI 
will be selected based on merit. Short-term contracts from 6 months to 1 year will be offered. 
The research associates will support the work of the network, conduct research, and promote 
capacity development on a sustained basis.  
 
4.  Trade  Economist  or  Macroeconomist  (international,  individual,  9  person-
months, intermittent) 
 
4.  The economist should have a postgraduate degree in economics, law, public policy or 
equivalent, and substantial experience in the area of international economics and Asian regional 
cooperation and integration. Excellent written and oral communications skills are required. In 
consultation with the OREI team leader, the economist will 
(i)  Prepare  a  paper  assessing  policy  implications  of  two  to  three  alternative 
scenarios for trade-led recovery and regional cooperation and integration in Asia 
(ii)  Prepare a practical manual for services trade negotiations in Asia. The manual 
will cover the economics of services trade and should be targeted at negotiators 
for subregional and regionwide agreements 
(iii)  Prepare  three  to  four  policy  briefs  on  recent  economic  and  trade  policy 
developments for rapid web-based dissemination. Each brief should be written in 
nontechnical style suitable for an audience such as policymakers 
(iv)  Undertake preparatory work for meetings of trade ministers including preparing 
speeches, agendas, and background materials and liaising with officials  
(v)  Make presentations at regional fora and training courses as required 
(vi)  Manage the organization of conferences and training courses 
(vii)  Review outputs of research associates including papers, policy briefs, and 
presentations.  
 
5.  Web Developer (national, individual, 6 person-months, intermittent)

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
5.  The  web  developer  should  have  extensive  experience  in  designing  and  developing 
websites that contain data and information on Asian economic integration and trade. Under the 
supervision of the project manager, the web developer will  
(i)  Design and develop the network website 
(ii)  Develop and maintain the content management system for the website 
(iii)  Develop and maintain the content database 
(iv)  Post content on the staging server for uploading to the production server 
(v)  Coordinate on web administration and database issues 
(vi)  Produce website statistics and maintain database for logs 
(vii)  Develop procedures and guidelines for website administration, development, and 
content population 
(viii)  Submit user guide, documentation, and technical specifications for the website. 
 
B.   International Resource Persons (2 person-months, individual, intermittent) 
6.  The TA will require the services of a pool of regional resource persons and policy 
experts  to  make  presentations  and/or  encourage  discussions  during  conferences  and 
workshops in this project. They will have recognized expertise in international trade, regional 
integration, and new trade issues. The resource persons can come from the public or private 
sectors and international or regional organizations.
